did.abstract: The National Alliance for the Mentally Ill is a grassroots support and advocacy group for the mentally ill and their families. This record group focuses on the Michigan chapters of NAMI Lansing and NAMI Michigan. Records in this collection include annual reports, bylaws, meeting minutes and agendas, correspondence, event materials, educational and advocacy program materials, brochures, newspapers, newsletters, resource guides, and various other printed materials.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This record group was donated by NAMI Michigan (donor no. 8745) in August 1998 The bulk of the record group was donated on February 8, 2012. Additional materials were received on June 5, 2012.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, NAMI Michigan records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The National Alliance for the Mentally Ill (NAMI) was founded in April of 1979. It comprised of various support groups for parents of adults with mental illness. NAMI soon developed into having many affiliated groups within communities around the United States. In 1999, those groups changed their names to NAMI in order to become a nationally recognized organization. Now it is the nation's largest grassroots mental health organization that exists, not only for parents of adults with mental illness, but also for families, friends, individuals, and business that have come together to provide support, education, and advocacy for all who have been affected by mental illness.

In 1974 the Oasis Fellowship (now NAMI Lansing) was formed in Lansing, Michigan in order to assist with housing arrangements for the mentally ill leaving state hospitals. It was also one of the first groups for family members, not just parents, of persons with mental illness. Since then, the organization has evolved into the "Tri-county's Voice on Mental Illness," and has expanded their mission to "improve the lives of those who suffer from neurobiological brain disorders and their families through support, education, advocacy, and research" (NAMI Lansing Mission Statement, 2012).

By January 1986, many more mental illness support and advocacy groups had developed and banded together to form NAMI Michigan. Their mission is to work at the state level to "improve the quality of life for persons, families and others, who are affected by mental illness, including children with serious emotional disorders, through support, education, advocacy and research"(NAMI Michigan Mission Statement, 2012).

scopecontent.p: The records of NAMI Michigan and NAMI Lansing document the dedicated efforts of the groups in providing support, education, advocacy, and research for the mentally ill and their families. The primary focus of their work has evolved into building a community for all those affected by mental illness. The series in the record group are: Administrative Files, Correspondence, Events, Programs, Publications/Printed Materials, and Miscellaneous.

scopecontent.p: The Administrative Files consist of annual reports, by-laws, meeting agendas and minutes, and various other documents from the Alliance for the Mentally Ill of Michigan, NAMI Lansing, NAMI Michigan, and the State Alliance for the Mentally Ill. It also includes various administrative documents and correspondence pertaining to other related mental illness support and advocacy groups.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence are comprised of letters, documents, and miscellaneous papers collected by Arlie Kinnee (Forensic Committee Chair, AMIM), Norma Prouty (AMI Education sub-committee), and Betty Smith (AMI OASIS Liaison with the Community Mental Health Board). This series highlights their individual involvement in NAMI and various other mental illness groups. Also included in this series are correspondence and miscellaneous documents pertaining to AMIM collected by Embert and Kalinich (no other names or titles given).

scopecontent.p: The Events series includes brochures, flyers, schedules, programs, and various other materials from forums, conferences, and conventions pertaining to mental illness in the state of Michigan.

did.unittitle: Family Focus Group on Valued Outcomes of Psychosocial Programs conducted by Esther Onaga 1995
Michigan Department of Mental Health/Department of Social Services/ Michigan Coalition Against Domestic Violence Statewide Conference Proceedings December, 1987
Northern Michigan Regional Alliance for the Mentally Ill Conference 1995-1996

scopecontent.p: The Programs series has materials from projects, training, and educational programs that focus on providing support for those with mental illness.

did.unittitle: Managing Persons with Mental Disabilities: A Curriculum Guide for Police Trainers, 1989
Michigan Self-Help Clearinghouse: A Program of Michigan Protection and Advocacy Service 1994
My Sister's Sister-- A professional play to promote the understanding of mental illness, 1999
Supported Employment Technical Assistance Project, Employment Training Specialist Series -- Follow Along Services Participant Manual November 1987

scopecontent.p: The Publications/Printed Materials include brochures, flyers, mailers, news releases, newspapers, and newsletters from various mental illness support and advocacy groups from around Michigan. The proposals and reports in this series mainly revolve around preventing violence towards the mentally ill, especially mentally ill women. This series also includes a number of resource guides for families dealing with mental illness.
